channel.title: Posts on TRxiv2
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on TRxiv2

item.title: addiction medicine
item.description: Extracellular Matrix Abnormalities in the Hippocampus of Subjects with Substance Use Disorder Authors: Valeri, J.; Stiplosek, C.; O'Donovan, S. M.; Sinclair, D.; Grant, K. A.; Bollavarapu, R.; Platt, D. M.; Stockmeier, C. A.; Gisabella, B.; Pantazopoulos, H. Score: 5.1, Published: 2023-09-08 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.07.23295222 Contextual triggers are significant factors contributing to relapse in substance use disorders (SUD). Emerging evidence points to a critical role of extracellular matrix (ECM) molecules as mediators of reward memories.

item.title: allergy and immunology
item.description: Observational Study of Repeat Immunoadsorption (RIA) in Post-COVID ME/CFS Patients with Elevated Beta-2-Adrenergic Receptor Autoantibodies Authors: Stein, E.; Heindrich, C.; Wittke, K.; Kedor, C.; Kim, L.; Freitag, H.; Krueger, A.; Toelle, M.; Scheibenbogen, C. Score: 407.8, Published: 2023-09-01 DOI: 10.1101/2023.08.31.23294813 There is increasing evidence for an autoimmune aetiology in post-infectious Myalgic Encephalomyelitis/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (ME/CFS). SARS-CoV-2 has now become the main trigger for ME/CFS. We have already conducted two small proof-of-concept studies of IgG depletion by immunoadsorption (IA) in post-infectious ME/CFS, which showed efficacy in most patients.

item.title: animal behavior and cognition
item.description: Flexibility of tandem leaders resolves traffic jams during colony relocation in an ant Authors: Pathak, M. K.; Annagiri, S. Score: 26.2, Published: 2023-09-13 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.13.557616 Ants, renowned for their intricate social behaviors, exhibit remarkable collective movement patterns that enable them to forage and tunnel efficiently. Despite significant research into their navigation skills and traffic avoidance mechanisms mostly in the context of central-place foraging, the dynamics of bi-directional movement during colony relocation remains an underexplored domain.

item.title: biochemistry
item.description: Glutamylation of Npm2 and Nap1 acidic disordered regions increases DNA charge mimicry to enhance chaperone efficiency Authors: Lorton, B. M.; Warren, C.; Ilyas, H.; Nandigrami, P.; Hegde, S.; Cahill, S.; Lehman, S. M.; Shabanowitz, J.; Hunt, D.; Fiser, A.; Cowburn, D.; Shechter, D. Score: 16.0, Published: 2023-09-19 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.18.558337 Histone chaperones-structurally diverse, non-catalytic proteins enriched with acidic intrinsically disordered regions (IDRs)-protect histones from spurious nucleic acid interactions and guide their deposition into and out of nucleosomes.

item.title: bioengineering
item.description: Complete substitution with modified nucleotides suppresses the early interferon response and increases the potency of self-amplifying RNA Authors: McGee, J. E.; Kirsch, J. R.; Kenney, D.; Chavez, E.; Shih, T.-Y.; Douam, F.; Wong, W. W.; Grinstaff, M. W. Score: 25.3, Published: 2023-09-17 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.15.557994 Self-amplifying RNA (saRNA) will revolutionize vaccines and in situ therapeutics by enabling protein expression for longer duration at lower doses. However, a major barrier to saRNA efficacy is the potent early interferon response triggered upon cellular entry, resulting in saRNA degradation and translational inhibition.

item.title: bioinformatics
item.description: Rendering protein mutation movies with MutAmore Authors: Weissenow, K.; Rost, B. Score: 39.6, Published: 2023-09-17 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.15.557870 We introduce MutAmore, a bioinformatics tool that renders individual photos of, e.g., protein three-dimensional (3D) structures for protein mutations into an easily understandable movie format. MutAmore provides a streamlined pipeline casting single amino-acid variations (SAVs) into a dynamic 3D protein mutation movie which provides a qualitative perspective on the mutational landscape of a protein.

item.title: biophysics
item.description: Secreted footprints let cells switch between confined, oscillatory, and exploratory migration Authors: Ipina, E. P.; D'Alessandro, J.; Ladoux, B.; Camley, B. A. Score: 22.6, Published: 2023-09-16 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.14.557437 For eukaryotic cells to heal wounds, respond to immune signals, or metastasize, they must migrate, often by adhering to extracellular matrix. Cells may also secrete matrix factors, leaving behind a footprint that influences their crawling. Recent experiments showed that epithelial cells on micropatterned adhesive stripes move persistently in regions they have previously crawled over, where footprints have been formed, but barely advance into unexplored regions, creating an oscillatory migration of increasing amplitude.

item.title: cancer biology
item.description: Identification of astrocyte-driven pseudolineages reveals clinical stratification and therapeutic targets in Glioblastoma Authors: Foerster, L. C.; Kaya, O.; Wust, V.; Bekavac, M.; Ziegler, K. C.; Akcay, V.; Stinchcombe, N.; Gesteira Perez, N.; Ma, X.; Sadik, A.; Le, P. U.; Petrecca, K.; Opitz, C.; Liu, H.; Wirtz, C. R.; Anders, S.; Goncalves, A.; Martin-Villalba, A. Score: 28.3, Published: 2023-09-17 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.15.557713 Cancer research has predominantly targeted genetic mutations, while only recently has attention shifted to understanding tumor cell-stages.

item.title: cardiovascular medicine
item.description: Neurodegeneration is strongly linked to heart failure severity and outcomes: framing the cardiocerebral syndrome Authors: Wurm, R.; Prausmueller, S.; Ponleitner, M.; Spinka, G.; Weidenhammer, A.; Arfsten, H.; Heitzinger, G.; Panagiotides, N. G.; Bartko, P.; Goliasch, G.; Stoegmann, E.; Hengstenberg, C.; Huelsmann, M.; Pavo, N. Score: 1.2, Published: 2023-09-15 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.15.23295547 Background and ObjectivesCognitive impairment is prevalent in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), affecting self-care and outcomes.

item.title: cell biology
item.description: Sequential membrane- and protein-bound organelles compartmentalize genomes during phage infection Authors: Armbruster, E.; Lee, J.; Hutchings, J.; VanderWal, A.; Enustun, E.; Adler, B.; Aindow, A.; Deep, A.; Rodriguez, Z.; Morgan, C.; Ghassemian, M.; Charles, E.; Cress, B.; Savage, D.; Doudna, J.; Pogliano, K.; Corbett, K.; Villa, E.; Pogliano, J. Score: 38.4, Published: 2023-09-21 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.20.558163 Eukaryotic viruses assemble compartments required for genome replication, but no such organelles are known to be essential for prokaryotic viruses.

item.title: dermatology
item.description: Testing the Limits of Language Models: A Conversational Framework for Medical AI Assessment Authors: Johri, S.; Jeong, J.; Tran, B. A.; Schlessinger, D. I.; Wongvibulsin, S.; Cai, Z. R.; Daneshjou, R.; Rajpurkar, P. Score: 39.3, Published: 2023-09-12 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.12.23295399 Large Language Models (LLMs) show promise for medical diagnosis, but traditional evaluations using static exam questions overlook the complexity of real-world clinical dialogues. We introduce a multi-agent conversational framework where doctor-AI and patient-AI agents interact to diagnose medical conditions, evaluated by a grader-AI agent and medical experts.

item.title: developmental biology
item.description: CXCR3-CXCL11 signaling restricts angiogenesis and promotes pericyte recruitment Authors: Goeckel, M. E.; Lee, J.; Levitas, A.; Colijn, S.; Mun, G.; Burton, Z.; Chintalapati, B.; Yin, Y.; Abello, J.; Stratman, A. N. Score: 14.1, Published: 2023-09-17 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.16.557842 Endothelial cell (EC)-pericyte interactions are known to remodel in response to hemodynamic forces, yet there is a lack of mechanistic understanding of the signaling pathways that underlie these events. Here, we have identified a novel signaling network regulated by blood flow in ECs--the chemokine receptor, CXCR3, and one of its ligands, CXCL11--that delimits EC angiogenic potential and suppresses pericyte recruitment during development through regulation of pdgfb expression in ECs.

item.title: ecology
item.description: A novel spawning survey: identifying spawning times and locations of jack mackerel in a semi-closed bay using environmental DNA analysis Authors: Tsuji, S.; Murakami, H.; Masuda, R. Score: 18.9, Published: 2023-09-12 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.10.557099 Understanding spawning ecology is vital for species/population management and conservation. Conventional surveys for this, however, are generally time- and labour-demanding and invasive. To overcome these challenges, environmental DNA (eDNA) analysis has emerged as a promising spawning survey method.

item.title: endocrinology
item.description: Systematic Review of Treatment of Beta-Cell Monogenic Diabetes Authors: Naylor, R. N.; Patel, K. A.; Kettunen, J. L. T.; Männistö, J. M. E.; Stoy, J.; Beltrand, J.; Polak, M.; ADA/EASD PMDI, ; Vilsobll, T.; Greeley, S. A. W.; Hattersley, A. T.; Tuomi, T. Score: 1.2, Published: 2023-09-22 DOI: 10.1101/2023.05.12.23289807 Background: Beta-cell monogenic forms of diabetes are the area of diabetes care with the strongest support for precision medicine. We reviewed treatment of hyperglycemia in GCK-related hyperglycemia, HNF1A- HNF4A- and HNF1B-diabetes, Mitochondrial diabetes (MD) due to m.

item.title: epidemiology
item.description: Ventilation during COVID-19 in a school for students with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDD). Authors: Zand, M. S.; Spallina, S.; Ross, A.; Zandi, K.; Pawlowski, A.; Seplaki, C.; Herington, J.; Corbett, A.; Kaukeinen, K.; Freedman, E.; Holden-Wiltse, J.; Alcantara, L.; Li, D.; Cameron, A.; Beaumont, N.; Dozier, A.; Dewhurst, S.; Foxe, J. Score: 61.4, Published: 2023-09-20 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.08.23295268 BackgroundThis study examined the correlation of classroom ventilation (air exchanges per hour (ACH)) and exposure to CO2 [&ge;]1,000 ppm with the incidence of SARS-CoV-2 over a 20-month period in a specialized school for students with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDD).

item.title: evolutionary biology
item.description: Self-assembling viral histones unravel early nucleosome evolution Authors: Irwin, N. A. T.; Richards, T. A. Score: 51.2, Published: 2023-09-22 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.20.558576 Nucleosomes are a core-component of eukaryotic nuclei, forming the structural basis of chromatin and co-ordinating processes from gene expression to chromosome segregation. Composed of a DNA-protein complex consisting of the four individual histones, H2A, H2B, H3, and H4, the nucleosome and its associated functions were key innovations during eukaryotic evolution.

item.title: genetic and genomic medicine
item.description: Genetic architecture of telomere length in 462,675 UK Biobank whole-genome sequences Authors: Burren, O. S.; Dhindsa, R.; Deevi, S. V. V.; Wen, S.; Nag, A.; Mitchell, J.; Hu, F.; Smith, K. R.; Razdan, N.; Olsson, H.; Platt, A.; Codd, V.; Nelson, C.; Samani, N.; March, R.; Wasilewski, S.; Carss, K.; Fabre, M.; Wang, Q.; Pangalos, M.; Petrovski, S. Score: 13.2, Published: 2023-09-19 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.18.23295715 Telomeres protect the ends of chromosomes from damage, and genetic regulation of their length is associated with human disease and ageing.

item.title: genetics
item.description: Higher-order combinatorial chromatin perturbations by engineered CRISPR-Cas12a for functional genomics Authors: Hsiung, C. C.- S.; Wilson, C. M.; Sambold, N. A.; Dai, R.; Chen, Q.; Misiukiewicz, S.; Arab, A.; Teyssier, N.; O'Loughlin, T.; Cofsky, J.; Shi, J.; Gilbert, L. A. Score: 34.7, Published: 2023-09-18 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.18.558350 Multiplexed genetic perturbations are critical for testing functional interactions among coding or non-coding genetic elements. Compared to DNA cutting, repressive chromatin formation using CRISPR interference (CRISPRi) avoids genotoxicity and is more effective for perturbing non-coding regulatory elements in pooled assays.

item.title: genomics
item.description: Single-cell nascent RNA sequencing using click-chemistry unveils coordinated transcription Authors: Mahat, D. B.; Tippens, N. D.; Martin-Rufino, J. D.; Waterton, S. K.; Fu, J.; Blatt, S. E.; Sharp, P. A. Score: 43.4, Published: 2023-09-19 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.15.558015 Transcription is the primary regulatory step in gene expression. Divergent transcription initiation from promoters and enhancers produces stable RNAs from genes and unstable RNAs from enhancers1-5. Nascent RNA capture and sequencing assays simultaneously measure gene and enhancer activity in cell populations6-9.

item.title: geriatric medicine
item.description: Proteomic aging clock predicts mortality and risk of common age-related diseases in diverse populations Authors: Argentieri, M. A.; Xiao, S.; Bennett, D.; Winchester, L.; Nevado-Holgado, A. J.; Albukhari, A.; Yao, P.; Mazidi, M.; Lv, J.; Li, L.; Adams, C. J.; Clarke, R.; Amin, N.; Chen, Z.; van Duijn, C. M. Score: 18.1, Published: 2023-09-13 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.13.23295486 Circulating plasma proteins play key roles in human health and could be used to measure biological aging to predict risk of mortality, disease, and multimorbidity beyond chronological age.

item.title: health economics
item.description: A Literature Review and Meta-Analysis of the Effects of Lockdowns on COVID-19 Mortality - II Authors: Herby, J.; Jonung, L.; Hanke, S. Score: 225.6, Published: 2023-09-05 DOI: 10.1101/2023.08.30.23294845 The purpose of this systematic review and meta-analysis is to determine the effect of lockdowns on COVID-19 mortality based on available empirical evidence. Lockdowns are defined as the imposition of at least one compulsory, non-pharmaceutical intervention (NPI). We employ a systematic search and screening procedure in which 19,646 studies are identified that could potentially address the purpose of our study.

item.title: health informatics
item.description: Randomized Controlled Trials Evaluating AI in Clinical Practice: A Scoping Evaluation Authors: Han, R.; Acosta, J. N.; Shakeri, Z.; Ioannidis, J.; Topol, E.; Rajpurkar, P. Score: 86.6, Published: 2023-09-13 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.12.23295381 BackgroundArtificial intelligence (AI) has emerged as a promising tool in healthcare, with numerous studies indicating its potential to perform as well or better than clinicians. However, a considerable portion of these AI models have only been tested retrospectively, raising concerns about their true effectiveness and potential risks in real-world clinical settings.

item.title: health systems and quality improvement
item.description: Healthcare system barriers impacting the care of Canadians with myalgic encephalomyelitis: a scoping review Authors: Hussein, S.; Eiriksson, L.; MacQuarrie, M.; Merriam, S.; Dalton, M.; Stein, E.; Twomey, R. Score: 20.4, Published: 2023-09-22 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.20.23295809 Background: Myalgic encephalomyelitis (ME, also known as chronic fatigue syndrome or ME/CFS) is a debilitating, complex, multi-system illness. Developing a comprehensive understanding of the multiple and interconnected barriers to optimal care will help advance strategies and care models to improve quality of life for people living with ME in Canada.

item.title: hiv aids
item.description: Assessing the potential population-level impacts of HIV self-testing distribution among key populations in Cote d'Ivoire, Mali, and Senegal: a mathematical modelling analysis Authors: Silhol, R.; Maheu-Giroux, M.; Soni, N.; Simo Fotso, A.; Rouveau, N.; Vautier, A.; Doumenc-Aidara, C.; Geoffroy, O.; N'Guessan, K. N.; Sidibe, Y.; Kabemba, O. K.; Gueye, P. A.; Mukandavire, C.; Vickerman, P.; Keita, A.; Ndour, C. T.; Ehui, E.; Larmarange, J.; Boily, M.-C.; The ATLAS Team, Score: 1.

item.title: immunology
item.description: Antigenicity and infectivity characterization of SARS-CoV-2 BA.2.86 Authors: Yang, S.; Yu, Y.; Jian, F.; Song, W.; Yisimayi, A.; Chen, X.; Xu, Y.; Wang, P.; Yu, L.; Wang, J.; Niu, X.; Wang, J.; Xiao, T.; An, R.; Wang, Y.; Gu, Q.; Shao, F.; Jin, R.; Shen, Z.; Wang, Y.; Cao, Y. R. Score: 653.5, Published: 2023-09-04 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.01.555815 The recently identified SARS-CoV-2 variant, BA.2.86, which carries a substantial number of Spike mutations, has raised a global alarm.

item.title: infectious diseases
item.description: Safety and Immunogenicity of XBB.1.5-Containing mRNA Vaccines Authors: Chalkias, S.; McGhee, N.; Whatley, J. L.; Essink, B.; Brosz, A.; Tomassini, J. E.; Girard, B.; Wu, K.; Edwards, D. K.; Nasir, A.; Lee, D.; Avena, L. E.; Feng, J.; Deng, W.; Montefiori, D. C.; Baden, L. R.; Miller, J. M.; Das, R. Score: 3361.5, Published: 2023-09-07 DOI: 10.1101/2023.08.22.23293434 BackgroundSubvariants of the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) omicron XBB-lineage have the potential to escape immunity provided by prior infection or vaccination.

item.title: intensive care and critical care medicine
item.description: Conventional and unconventional T cell responses contribute to the prediction of clinical outcome and causative bacterial pathogen in sepsis patients Authors: Burton, R. J.; Raffray, L.; Moet, L. M.; Cuff, S. M.; White, D. A.; Baker, S. E.; Moser, B.; O'Donnell, V. B.; Ghazal, P.; Morgan, M. P.; Artemiou, A.; Eberl, M. Score: 5.7, Published: 2023-09-13 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.13.23295490 Sepsis is characterised by a dysfunctional host response to infection culminating in life-threatening organ failure that requires complex patient management and rapid intervention.

item.title: microbiology
item.description: Genome-wide Characterization of Diverse Bacteriophages Enabled by RNA-Binding CRISPRi Authors: Adler, B. A.; Al-Shimary, M. J.; Patel, J. R.; Ambruster, E.; Colognori, D.; Charles, E. J.; Miller, K. V.; Lahiri, A.; Trinidad, M.; Boger, R.; Nomburg, J.; Beurnier, S.; Cui, M. L.; Barrangou, R.; Mutalik, V. K.; Schoeniger, J. S.; Pogliano, J. A.; Savage, D. F.; Doudna, J. A.; Cress, B. F. Score: 70.0, Published: 2023-09-18 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.18.558157 Bacteriophages constitute one of the largest sources of unknown gene content in the biosphere.

item.title: molecular biology
item.description: CCAR1 promotes DNA repair via an unanticipated role in alternative splicing Authors: Karasu, M. E.; Joseph, B.; Mironov, A.; Schroeder, M. S.; Gvozdenovic, A.; Zavolan, M.; Corn, J. E. Score: 18.4, Published: 2023-09-18 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.18.557780 DNA repair is directly performed by hundreds of core factors and indirectly regulated by thousands of others. We massively expanded a CRISPR inhibition and Cas9-editing screening system to discover factors indirectly modulating homology directed repair (HDR) in the context of [~]18000 individual gene knockdowns.

item.title: nephrology
item.description: Deep learning on electronic medical records identifies distinct subphenotypes of diabetic kidney disease driven by genetic variations in the Rho pathway Authors: Paranjpe, I.; Wang, X.; Anandakrishnan, N.; Haydak, J.; Van Vleck, T. T.; Defronzo, S.; Li, Z.; Mendoza, A.; Liu, R.; Fu, J.; Forrest, I.; Zhou, W.; Lee, K.; O'Hagan, R.; Dellepiane, S.; Menon, K.; Gulamali, F.; Kamat, S.; Gusella, G. L.; Charney, A. W.; Hofer, I.; Cho, J.

item.title: neurology
item.description: Millimeter-sized battery-free epidural cortical stimulators Authors: Woods, J. E.; Singer, A.; Alrashdan, F.; Tan, W.; Tan, C.; Sheth, S. A.; Sheth, S. A.; Robinson, J. T. Score: 25.3, Published: 2023-09-15 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.13.23295460 Refractory neurological and psychiatric disorders are increasingly treated with brain stimulation therapies using implanted neuromodulation devices. Current commercially available stimulation systems, however, are limited by the need for implantable pulse generators and wired power; the complexity of this architecture creates multiple failure points including lead fractures, migration, and infection.

item.title: neuroscience
item.description: Neurological Imprints of Boys' Love Culture: Shaping Sexual Orientation Identity in the Digital Age's Young females Authors: Yanan, C.; Na, A.; Xiaowei, J.; Yingying, C.; Huihui, N.; Shuoyan, H. Score: 539.3, Published: 2023-09-21 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.18.558088 With the omnipresence of social media, Boys' Love (BL) culture has found a burgeoning audience among young females. While this cultural phenomenon offers a platform for self-expression to some, its potential implications remain underexplored. This study investigates whether immersion in BL culture impacts the process of young females forming self-recognition and identification of sexual orientation.

item.title: nutrition
item.description: Dietary sulfur amino acid restriction in humans with overweight and obesity: a translational randomized controlled trial Authors: Olsen, T.; Stolt, E.; Ovrebo, B.; Elshorbagy, A.; Tore, E. C.; Lee-Oedegard, S.; Troensegaard, H.; Johannessen, H.; Doeland, B.; Vo, A. A. D.; Dahl, A. F.; Svendsen, K.; Thoresen, M.; Refsum, H.; Rising, R.; Barvikova, K.; Greevenbroek, M. v.; Kozich, V.; Retterstol, K.; Vinknes, K. J. Score: 3.9, Published: 2023-09-10 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.09.23295155

item.title: oncology
item.description: A clinicogenomic model including GARD predicts outcome for radiation treated patients with HPV+ oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma Authors: Ho, E.; DeCecco, L.; Cavalieri, S.; Sedor, G.; Hoebers, F.; Brakenhoff, R.; Scheckenbach, K.; Poli, T.; Yang, K.; Scarborough, J.; Campbell, S.; Koyfman, S.; Eschrich, S. A.; Caudell, J.; Kattan, M. W.; Licitra, L.; Torres-Roca, J.; Scott, J. G. Score: 20.3, Published: 2023-09-14 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.14.23295538 BackgroundTreatment decision-making in oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma (OPSCC) includes clinical stage, HPV status, and smoking history.

item.title: orthopedics
item.description: Real-world gait and turning in individuals scheduled for total knee arthroplasty Authors: Boekesteijn, R. J.; Keijsers, N. L. W.; Defoort, K.; Mancini, M.; Bruning, F. J.; El-Gohary, M.; Geurts, A. C. H.; Smulders, K. Score: 3.1, Published: 2023-09-13 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.13.23295243 ObjectiveTo compare real-world gait and turning between individuals scheduled for total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and healthy controls, using continuous monitoring with inertial measurement units (IMUs). DesignReal-world gait and turning data were collected for 5-7 days in individuals scheduled for TKA (n=34) and healthy controls in the same age range (n=32) using IMUs on the feet and lower back.

item.title: pain medicine
item.description: Effects of Savoring Meditation on Positive Emotions and Pain-Related Brain Function: A Mechanistic Randomized Controlled Trial in People With Rheumatoid Arthritis Authors: Finan, P.; Hunt, C.; Keaser, M. L.; Smith, K.; Lerman, S.; Bingham, C. O.; Barrett, F.; Garland, E. L.; Zeidan, F.; Seminowicz, D. A. Score: 3.6, Published: 2023-09-08 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.07.23294949 Positive emotions are a promising target for intervention in chronic pain, but mixed findings across trials to date suggest that existing interventions may not be optimized to efficiently engage the target.

item.title: paleontology
item.description: Forensic Facial Approximation of Achondroplastic Dwarf from Medieval Cemetery in Central Europe Authors: Moraes, C.; Krenz-Niedbała, M.; Łukasik, S.; Prada, C. S. Score: 63.5, Published: 2023-08-28 DOI: 10.1101/2023.08.26.553833 Achondroplasia (ACH, achondroplastic dwarfism) represents the most common form of skeletal dysplasia, occurring in c. 4 out of every 100,000 births. This study presents a computer-based facial approximation of the skull of a male individual suffering from ACH, who died at 30-45 years of age and was buried in ekno, Poland between the 9th and 11th centuries AD.

item.title: pathology
item.description: Native ultrastructure of fresh human brain vitrified directly from autopsy revealed by cryo-electron tomography with cryo-plasma focused ion beam milling Authors: Creekmore, B. C.; Kixmoeller, K.; Black, B. E.; Lee, E. B.; Chang, Y.-W. Score: 26.6, Published: 2023-09-17 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.13.557623 Ultrastructure of human brain tissue has traditionally been examined using electron microscopy (EM) following chemical fixation, staining, and mechanical sectioning, which limit attainable resolution and introduce artifacts. Alternatively, cryo-electron tomography (cryo-ET) offers the potential to image unfixed cellular samples at higher resolution while preserving their native structures, but it requires samples to be frozen free from crystalline ice and thin enough to image via transmission EM.

item.title: pharmacology and therapeutics
item.description: Atazanavir/ritonavir increased tizoxanide exposure from oral nitazoxanide through pharmacokinetic interaction in healthy volunteers Authors: Akinloye, A.; Oyedeji, T.; Eniayewu, O.; Adeagbo, B.; Bolaji, O.; Rannard, S.; Owen, A.; Olagunju, A. Score: 2.0, Published: 2023-09-22 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.20.23295544 Aims: Nitazoxanide is a broad-spectrum antiviral with potential application in a number of viral infections. Its use is limited by gastrointestinal side effects associated with increasing dose. In this study, we investigated the possibility of enhancing the exposure of its active metabolite, tizoxanide, through pharmacokinetic interaction with atazanavir/ritonavir.

item.title: pharmacology and toxicology
item.description: Self-supervised deep learning uncovers the semantic landscape of drug-induced latent mitochondrial phenotypes Authors: Natekar, P.; Wang, Z.; Arora, M.; Hakozaki, H.; Schoeneberg, J. Score: 75.5, Published: 2023-09-14 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.13.557636 Imaging-based high-content screening aims to identify substances that modulate cellular phenotypes. Traditional approaches screen compounds for their ability to shift disease phenotypes toward healthy phenotypes, but these end point-based screens lack an atlas-like mapping between phenotype and cell state that covers the full spectrum of possible phenotypic responses.

item.title: physiology
item.description: Inhibition of mammalian mtDNA transcription paradoxically activates liver fatty acid oxidation to reverse diet-induced hepatosteatosis and obesity Authors: Jiang, S.; Yuan, T.; Kremer, L. S.; Rosenberger, F. A.; Hansen, F. M.; Borg, M.; Rubalcava-Gracia, D.; Mennuni, M.; Filograna, R.; Alsina, D.; Misic, J.; Koolmeister, C.; Ren, L.; Andersson, O.; Unger, A.; Bergbrede, T.; Lucrezia, R. D.; Wilbom, R.; Zierath, J. R.; Krook, A.; Giavalisco, P.; Mann, M.; Larsson, N.-G.

item.title: plant biology
item.description: Plant-based production of diverse human milk oligosaccharides Authors: Barnum, C. R.; Paviani, B.; Couture, G.; Masarweh, C.; Chen, Y.; Huang, Y.-P.; Mills, D. A.; Lebrilla, C. B.; Barile, D.; Yang, M.; Shih, P. Score: 13.9, Published: 2023-09-20 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.18.558286 Human milk oligosaccharides (HMOs) are a diverse class of carbohydrates that aid in the health and development of infants. The vast health benefits of HMOs have made them a commercial target for microbial production; however, producing the ~130 structurally diverse HMOs at scale has proven difficult.

item.title: psychiatry and clinical psychology
item.description: Prenatal cannabis exposure is associated with focal brain differences that partially mediate associations with increased adolescent psychopathology Authors: Baranger, D. A.; Miller, A. P.; Gorelik, A. J.; Paul, S. E.; Hatoum, A. S.; Johnson, E. C.; Colbert, S. M. C.; Smyser, C. D.; Rogers, C. E.; Bijsterbosch, J. D.; Agrawal, A.; Bogdan, R. Score: 5.0, Published: 2023-09-20 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.19.23295792 Prenatal cannabis exposure (PCE) is associated with mental health problems, but the neurobiological mechanisms remain unknown.

item.title: public and global health
item.description: Estimating the population effectiveness of interventions against COVID-19 in France: a modelling study Authors: Ganser, I.; Buckeridge, D. L.; Heffernan, J. M.; Prague, M.; Thiebaut, R. Score: 11.5, Published: 2023-09-14 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.14.23295425 BackgroundNon-pharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) and vaccines have been widely used to manage the COVID-19 pandemic. However, uncertainty persists regarding the effectiveness of these interventions due to data quality issues, methodological challenges, and differing contextual factors. Accurate estimation of their effects is crucial for future epidemic preparedness.

item.title: radiology and imaging
item.description: Radiomic-Based Prediction of Lesion-Specific Systemic Treatment Response in Metastatic Disease Authors: Geady, C.; Abbas-Aghababazadeh, F.; Kohan, A.; Schuetze, S.; Shultz, D.; Haibe-Kains, B. Score: 1.2, Published: 2023-09-23 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.22.23294942 Despite sharing the same histologic classification, individual tumors in multi metastatic patients may present with different characteristics and varying sensitivities to anticancer therapies. In this study, we investigate the utility of radiomic biomarkers for prediction of lesion-specific treatment resistance in multi metastatic leiomyosarcoma patients.

item.title: rehabilitation medicine and physical therapy
item.description: HEART rate variability biofeedback breathing programme for LOng Covid dysautonomia (HEARTLOC): results of a feasibility study Authors: Corrado, J.; Iftekhar, N.; Halpin, S.; Li, M.; Tarrant, R.; Grimaldi, J.; Simms, A.; O'Connor, R. J.; Casson, A.; Sivan, M. Score: 10.2, Published: 2023-09-12 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.09.23295208 IntroductionPost-covid-19 syndrome, or Long covid (LC) refers to symptoms persisting 12 weeks after Covid-19 infection. LC comprises a wide range of dysautonomia symptoms, including fatigue, breathlessness, palpitations, dizziness, pain and brain fog.

item.title: scientific communication and education
item.description: Controlled experiment finds no detectable citation bump from Twitter promotion Authors: Branch, T.; C?te, I. M.; David, S. R.; Drew, J. A.; LaRue, M.; Marquez, M. C.; Parsons, E. C. M.; Rabaiotti, D.; Shiffman, D.; Steen, D. A.; Wild, A. L. Score: 202.6, Published: 2023-09-18 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.17.558161 Multiple studies across a variety of scientific disciplines have shown that the number of times that a paper is shared on Twitter (now called X) is correlated with the number of citations that paper receives.

item.title: synthetic biology
item.description: Computational design of sequence-specific DNA-binding proteins Authors: Glasscock, C. J.; Pecoraro, R.; McHugh, R.; Doyle, L. A.; Chen, W.; Boivin, O.; Lonnquist, B.; Na, E.; Politanska, Y.; Haddox, H. K.; Cox, D.; Norn, C.; Coventry, B.; Goreshnik, I.; Vafeados, D.; Lee, G. R.; Gordan, R.; Stoddard, B. L.; DiMaio, F.; Baker, D. Score: 170.1, Published: 2023-09-21 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.20.558720 Sequence-specific DNA-binding proteins (DBPs) play critical roles in biology and biotechnology, and there has been considerable interest in the engineering of DBPs with new or altered specificities for genome editing and other applications.

item.title: systems biology
item.description: Widespread transcriptional regulation from within transcribed regions in plants Authors: Voichek, Y.; Hristova, G.; Molla-Morales, A.; Weigel, D.; Nordborg, M. Score: 108.5, Published: 2023-09-17 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.15.557872 Animals and plants have evolved separately for over 1.5 billion years and independently invented multicellularity, suggesting a possible divergence in their mode of transcription regulation. Here, we set out to elucidate fundamental features of transcription regulatory sequences in plants. Using a massively parallel reporter assay in four species, we show that sequences downstream of the transcription start site (TSS) play a major role in controlling transcription.

item.title: zoology
item.description: Historical biogeography of New World Killifishes (Cyprinodontiformes: Funduloidea) recapitulates geographical history in the Gulf of Mexico watershed Authors: Hernandez, S. G.; Hoagstrom, C. W.; Matamoros, W. A. Score: 18.6, Published: 2023-09-11 DOI: 10.1101/2023.09.07.556706 We reconstructed the phylogenetic relationships of superfamily Funduloidea with a synthesis of its biogeographic history. We used DNA sequences from five genes for 135 species, with four fossil calibrations, to generate a time-calibrated phylogeny. We estimated diversification rates, ancestral areas (Nearctic or Neotropical), and ancestral habitat (coastal or upland), for each node.
